column4: How do I create a USB bootable Ubuntu disk if my only active system is Windows?
I can get to the "boot: " prompt.
I AM NOT ASKING HOW SOMETHING WORKS IN WIN!
I have the USB formatted and booting to Ubuntu.
It just stops at the "boot: " prompt.
Pendrivelinux tells me to use Universal-USB-Installer-1.8.6.4.exe, which I tried.
Yes. I've tried two different Ubuntu distributions: ubuntu-11.04-desktop-i386.iso and ubuntu-10.10-desktop-i386.iso.
Silly question, i know - but have you actually set up your BIOS to boot from USB?
Can you tell me what OS you're using right now, just so I can drag up some decent instructions?
have you used diskpart to confirm that the partition is actually active?
I tried to partition the USB flash drive but was unable to do so.
did it deny you access to it?
I didn't use diskpart. I assume that's an Ubuntu program?
OK, I'm gonna help you sort this.  Here's what I want you to do: Insert the USB stick, and open your start menu. Click run, and type compmgmt.msc
- so the disk is marked active, the partition is good, there are no errors... Does the drive have a drive letter assigned to it?
Looking at my notes, something may actually be wrong.  When a disk is bootable, the disk management area should show Healthy (Active, Boot) or simply Healthy (Boot)
